questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents to the OPD with excess facial hair for 6 months and delayed menstrual cycles. On evaluation, levels of free testosterone are increased. An ultrasound reveals normal uterus and normal ovaries on USG. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome/ disease (PCOS/PCOD) is a disorder of chronically abnormal ovarian function (oligo/anovulation) and hyperandrogenism frequently associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility, and hirsutism.

  • Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose  PCOS/PCOD: As per this criterion, at least 2 of 3 should be present:

    1. Oligo/anovulation (causes oligomenorrhea, 20 amenorrhea, and infertility)

    2. Hyperandrogenism: Biochemical or clinical (increased serum androgens or acne, hirsutism)

    3. 12 or more than 12 follicle 2-9 mm in size present within 1 or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume > 10 mL (pearl necklace pattern).

 

 

USG appearance of polycystic ovaries

 

  • As the patient in the question satisfies first 2 criteria, she is a case of PCOS

 

let's consider the other options:

 

Option. A. Adrenal Hyperplasia: Adrenal hyperplasia, particularly congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), can cause symptoms similar to PCOS, including hirsutism and menstrual irregularities, due to elevated androgens. However, it is usually diagnosed earlier in life and often has other associated adrenal hormone abnormalities.

 

Option. B. Idiopathic Hirsutism: Idiopathic hirsutism refers to hirsutism (excess hair growth) in the absence of any identifiable hormonal imbalance or ovarian/adrenal gland disorder. Given the increased free testosterone levels in this patient, idiopathic hirsutism is less likely.

 

Option. D. Testosterone Secreting Tumor: While a testosterone-secreting tumor can cause increased androgen levels and symptoms like hirsutism, these tumors are rare. The more common presentation of such tumors would include rapid onset of symptoms and markedly elevated testosterone levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is the most likely diagnosis in a young woman presenting with hirsutism, menstrual irregularities, and elevated free testosterone levels. The diagnosis of PCOS is based on a combination of clinical, biochemical, and ultrasound findings, and it is important to consider this condition in women with such symptoms.

 

Ref: Page no 401, Speroff’s Clinical Gynaecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD)?

 

  1. Testosterone> 2 ng/ml

  2. Infertility

  3. High FSH/LH ratio

  4. Fasting glucose/ insulin ratio > 4.5

  5. Polycystic appearance on 1 or both ovaries on ultrasound
questions.solution:
Ans. B. b, d, e

 

  • PCOS includes chronic non ovulation, hyperandrogenism associated with normal or raised estradiol level (E2), raised LH0 & low FSH/LH ratio.

  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based upon the presence of any two of the following three criteria (Rotterdam Criteria)

    1. Oligomenorrhoea/or anovulation (Delayed cycles and infertility)

    2. Hyperandrogenism (Clinical &/or biochemical)

    3. Polycystic ovaries (Ultrasound finding of 1 OR both ovaries)

  • On investigations, 

    • LH: FSH ratio is increased (3:1) i.e. LH is more than FSH

    • Increase free testosterone levels

    • Increase DHEAS

    • Fasting glucose: insulin ratio < 4.5

    • Sex hormone binding globulin decreases

 

Possible late sequelae of PCOD are:

 

  • Risk of developing diabetes mellitus (15%) due to insulin resistance

  • Risk of developing endometrial carcinoma due to elevated level of estrogen.

  • Risk of hypertension & cardiovascular disease due w abnormal lipid profile (dyslipidaemia)

 

Let us look at each option

 

Option. A. Testosterone > 2 ng/ml: Elevated testosterone levels are a hallmark of PCOS, reflecting the condition's hyperandrogenic state. However, a level > 2 ng/ml is quite high and not a typical threshold for PCOS diagnosis. Elevated testosterone in PCOS is usually more modest.

 

Option. B. Infertility: Correct. Infertility is a common complication of PCOS due to chronic anovulation (lack of ovulation). Many women with PCOS struggle with infertility or subfertility.

 

Option C. High FSH/LH Ratio: This is incorrect. In PCOS, the LH to FSH ratio is often elevated (reversed), not the FSH to LH ratio. A common finding is an LH to FSH ratio greater than 2:1.

 

Option. D. Fasting Glucose/Insulin Ratio > 4.5: Correct.  While insulin resistance is a feature of PCOS, this specific ratio is not a standard diagnostic criterion for the condition. PCOS is often associated with insulin resistance, but diagnostic criteria typically don't include a specific fasting glucose/insulin ratio.

 

Option E. Polycystic Appearance on 1 or Both Ovaries on Ultrasound: Correct. One of the diagnostic criteria for PCOS, according to the Rotterdam criteria, is the presence of polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, characterized by 12 or more follicles measuring 2-9 mm in diameter, or an increased ovarian volume (>10 cm³) in one or both ovaries.


Educational Objective: 

 

Polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD/PCOS) is characterized by features such as hyperandrogenism (e.g., elevated testosterone levels), infertility due to chronic anovulation, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. Understanding these features is key in the diagnosis and management of PCOS.

 

Ref: Page no 411, Speroff’s clinical gynaecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

choices.text: Marked elevation of LH in contrast to FSH
Elevation in the levels of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG)

questions.text: The biochemical chaanges in established cases of Stein-Leventhal syndrome are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elevation in the levels of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG)

 

  • Stein Leventhal syndrome is the older name of PCOS
  • In PCOS (Stein Leventhal syndrome) the levels of SHBG decrease
  • Other features of PCOS are
    • LH: FSH ratio is increased (3:1) i.e. LH is more than FSH
    • Increase free testosterone levels.
    • Increase DHEAS
    • Fasting glucose: insulin ratio < 4.5
    • Sex hormone binding globulin decreases.

 

Let's examine each statement:

 

Option. A. Marked elevation of LH in contrast to FSH: Correct. In PCOS, there is often a marked elevation of LH relative to FSH, leading to an increased LH:FSH ratio.

 

Option. B. Insulin Resistance: Correct. Insulin resistance is a common finding in PCOS, contributing to its pathophysiology. It is associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes and other metabolic complications in these patients.

 

Option C. Elevation of Plasma Testosterone: Correct. Hyperandrogenism, characterized by elevated levels of testosterone, is a hallmark of PCOS. This leads to symptoms such as hirsutism, acne, and androgenic alopecia.

 

Option. D. Elevation in the Levels of Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG): Incorrect. In PCOS, there is typically a decrease in the levels of SHBG. Lower levels of SHBG result in increased bioavailability of testosterone, contributing to the hyperandrogenic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: In PCOS, biochemical changes include an elevated LH:FSH ratio, insulin resistance, increased levels of plasma testosterone, and decreased levels of SHBG.

 

Ref: Page 411 Speroff’s Clinical Gynaecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in a 28-year-old obese woman presenting with Oligomenorrhea, infertility and hirsutism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Polycystic ovaries

 

A young woman presenting in the third decade with obesity, oligomenorrhea, infertility and hirsutism leaves no doubt for the diagnosis of PCOS.

 

According to Rotterdam criteria → PCOD is diagnosed if any 2 of 3 of the following criteria are being fulfilled:

 

  1. Ovulatory dysfunction such as oligomenorrhea or hyperandrogenism.
  2. Clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism
  3. USG criteria (1 or both ovaries showing polycystic appearance)

 

Since this woman has oligomenorrhea and hirsutism, SO2 of the criteria are being fulfilled.

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option. B. Endometriosis: It is a condition where endometrial tissue grows outside the uterus. It commonly presents with painful periods, chronic pelvic pain, and can be associated with infertility. However, it does not typically present with hirsutism or oligomenorrhea as primary symptoms.

 

Option C. Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID): PID is an infection of the female reproductive organs, often caused by sexually transmitted infections. It typically presents with pelvic pain, fever, and abnormal vaginal discharge.

 

Option. D. Cushing Syndrome: Cushing syndrome is caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. It can present with obesity, menstrual irregularities, and hirsutism. However, the other symptoms of Cushing's syndrome (like a round face, high blood pressure, and purple stretch marks) are not mentioned, making PCOS a more likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Educational Objective: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) should be highly suspected in women presenting with a combination of oligomenorrhea, infertility, hirsutism, and often obesity. PCOS is a complex endocrine disorder that impacts multiple aspects of health and is a common cause of infertility in women.

 

Ref: Page 400, Speroff’s clinical Gynaecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: Preeti, a 20-year-old girl presents with a history of rapidly developing hirsutism, severe acne and amenorrhea. Her BMI is 19. To establish the diagnosis, which would be the most appropriate blood test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Testosterone

 

For cases of virilisation and hirsutism, serum testosterone is the investigation of choice

 

  • A variety of ovarian neoplasms, both benign and malignant may produce testosterone and lead to virilization. Specifically, women with an abrupt onset, typically within several months, or sudden worsening of virilizing signs should prompt concern for a hormone producing ovarian or adrenal tumour.

  • Symptoms may include deepening of voice, frontal balding, severe acne, or hirsutism or both, increased muscle mass and clitoromegaly.

  • Accordingly, serum testosterone levels may be used to exclude these tumours. Free testosterone levels are more sensitive than total testosterone levels as an indicator of hyperandrogenism.

  • "Threshold values beyond 200 ng/dl of total testosterone warrant evaluation for an ovarian lesion".

  • Testosterone estimation is the best investigation in case of rapid onset hirsutism and amenorrhea.

  • M/C cause of rapid onset hirsutism in young females = Testosterone producing tumour

  • DHEA sulphate is produced exclusively by the adrenal gland. Therefore, serum DHEAS levels above 700 mcg/dl are highly sensitive for the presence of an adrenal neoplasm.

  • Adrenal imaging with abdominal CT or MRI is indicated for any patient with DHEAS levels that exceed this value.

 

Let us look at each option separately:

 

Option. A. 17-OH Progesterone: This test is used to evaluate adrenal gland function and diagnose congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), a condition that can cause symptoms similar to PCOS, including hirsutism and menstrual irregularities. However, the rapid onset of symptoms described is less typical for CAH.

 

Option. B. DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone): DHEA is an androgen produced by the adrenal glands. While elevated levels can contribute to hirsutism and acne, DHEA alone may not provide a definitive diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Testosterone: Correct. Elevated levels of testosterone are a key indicator of hyperandrogenism, which can manifest as hirsutism, acne, and menstrual irregularities. Measuring testosterone levels is crucial in diagnosing conditions like PCOS or androgen-secreting tumors, which can present with rapid onset of symptoms.

 

Option. D. LH: FSH Ratio: This ratio is often evaluated in the diagnosis of PCOS, as women with PCOS may have an elevated ratio. However, a normal ratio does not rule out PCOS, and it is not as directly indicative of hyperandrogenism as elevated testosterone levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When evaluating a young woman with rapid onset of hirsutism, severe acne, and amenorrhea, measuring serum testosterone levels is crucial for diagnosing conditions associated with hyperandrogenism, such as PCOS or androgen-secreting tumors.

 

Ref: Page 449, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

choices.text: Sonographic polycystic appearance of ovaries
Peripheral distribution of follicles on transvaginal ultrasonography

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Rotterdam criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Peripheral distribution of follicles on transvaginal ultrasonography

 

  1. Oligomenorrhea/ anovulation
  2. Clinical or biochemical sign of hyperandrogenism
  3. Ultrasound features of polycystic ovaries

 

Ultrasound features which are considered for diagnosis of polycystic ovaries includes the presence of these in one or both ovaries

 

  • ≥12 follicles measuring 2–9 mm throughout the entire ovary.
  • Increased ovarian volume of > 10 cm3

 

A single ovary complying these features is sufficient for diagnosing as polycystic ovaries(PCO)

 

Let us evaluate each option to identify which is not included in these criteria:

 

Option. A. Oligomenorrhea: Included. Oligomenorrhea, or infrequent menstrual periods, is one of the criteria under the Rotterdam guidelines for diagnosing PCOS. It reflects the chronic anovulation commonly seen in PCOS.

 

Option. B. Sonographic Polycystic Appearance of Ovaries: Included. The presence of polycystic ovaries on ultrasound is a part of the Rotterdam criteria. This is typically defined as having 12 or more follicles in each ovary measuring 2-9 mm in diameter, or increased ovarian volume.

 

Option C. Peripheral Distribution of Follicles on Transvaginal Ultrasonography: Not included. While the presence of multiple follicles is a criterion, the specific pattern of their distribution, such as a peripheral arrangement, is not a requirement for the diagnosis of PCOS as per the Rotterdam criteria.

 

Option. D. Clinical Signs of Hyperandrogenism: Included. Clinical signs of hyperandrogenism, such as hirsutism, acne, or androgenic alopecia, are part of the Rotterdam criteria. Alternatively, biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism can also fulfill this criterion.

 

Educational Objective: The Rotterdam criteria for the diagnosis of PCOS include at least two of the following: oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, clinical or biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. The specific distribution pattern of ovarian follicles is not a part of these diagnostic criteria.

 

Ref: Page 400, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

choices.text: Reduces production of FSH
Acts on androgen receptors and antagonizes it

questions.text: A 19y girl with PCOS is started on the combination pill shown below. What is the role of the progesterone component of this combination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Reduces ovarian androgen production

 

  • Androgen production in PCOD women usually is an LH-dependent process. PROGESTINS in oral contraceptives suppress pituitary LH secretion and thus also suppress ovarian androgen production.
  • Progestin in oral contraceptives inhibit 5α reductase activity in skin which decreases the production of dihydrotestosterone (DHT), the major nuclear androgen in hair follicles and sebaceous glands.

 

Let's consider the role of the progesterone component:

 

Option. A. Increases LH Production: Incorrect. Progestins in oral contraceptive pills (OCPs), including Drosperinone, do not increase LH production. Instead, they help suppress ovulation partly by inhibiting the release of gonadotropins like LH from the pituitary gland.

 

Option. B. Reduces Production of FSH: Progestins contribute to the suppression of FSH production, which is a mechanism involved in preventing ovulation. However, this is not the most direct effect of drospirenone in the context of PCOS treatment.

 

Option C. Acts on Androgen Receptors and Antagonizes it: Drosperinone has anti-androgenic properties, meaning it can counteract the effects of androgens. This action helps reduce symptoms like acne and hirsutism in PCOS but is not its primary mechanism of action in terms of ovarian androgen production.

 

Option. D. Reduces Ovarian Androgen Production: Correct. One of the key roles of drospirenone in OCPs for PCOS is to reduce ovarian androgen production. By suppressing gonadotropin release (LH and FSH), drospirenone reduces the stimulation of the ovaries, leading to decreased production of androgens.

 

Educational objective: In the treatment of PCOS, Drosperinone in combination oral contraceptive pills helps reduce ovarian androgen production by suppressing gonadotropin release. This action not only aids in regulating the menstrual cycle but also helps in managing hyperandrogenic symptoms such as acne and hirsutism commonly seen in PCOS.

 

Ref: Page 420, Speroff’s Clinical Gynaecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in PCOS except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Clitoromegaly

 

Clinical features seen in PCOD are:

 

  • Hirsutism
  • Acne
  • Androgenic alopecia
  • Increased facial hair
  • Menstrual irregularity

 

In PCOD there is increased androgen production which is LH mediated and lead to growth of terminal hairs on the face or body in a male pattern

 

Clitoromegaly is not seen in PCOD.

 

  • Hirsutism defined as excessive male pattern facial and body hair
  • Virilization is defined by the signs and symptoms of more severe androgen excess which include deepening of voice, clitoromegaly, balding and breast atrophy.
  • Hair is characterized as vellus that is fine, soft, and unpigmented or terminal i.e long, coarse and pigmented
  • In androgen sensitive areas androgen stimulates growth of longer, thicker, and darker hairs.
  • In hair follicles testosterone needs to be converted to dihydrotestosterone by 5α reductase. Dihydrotestosterone is the main hormone which plays a crucial role in hair growth.

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option. A. Androgenic Alopecia: Seen in PCOS. Androgenic alopecia, or male-pattern hair loss, can occur in PCOS due to the effects of elevated androgens on hair follicles.

 

Option. B. Increased Facial Hair: Seen in PCOS. Hirsutism, or increased facial and body hair in a male pattern, is a common feature of PCOS, resulting from increased androgen levels.

 

Option C. Clitoromegaly: Not seen in PCOS. Clitoromegaly, or an enlarged clitoris, is a sign of virilization and is more indicative of conditions with severe androgen excess, such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia or androgen-secreting tumors. It is not a characteristic feature of PCOS.

 

Option. D. Acne: Seen in PCOS. Acne is a common dermatological manifestation in PCOS, also related to elevated androgen levels.

 

Educational Objective: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by signs of hyperandrogenism, such as hirsutism, acne, and androgenic alopecia, along with menstrual irregularities. Clitoromegaly is not a typical feature of PCOS and is more indicative of conditions with more severe androgen excess.

 

Ref: Page 449, Speroff’s Clinical Gynaecological Endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: During evaluation of PCOS, a serum 17 –hydroxyprogesterone levels of 800 ng/dl was obtained. This value warrants the diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

 

CONGENITAL ADRENAL HYPERPLASIA is caused by adrenal enzyme deficiency of most commonly 21 hydroxylase that results in excessive adrenal androgen production.

 

  • Non classical or late onset CAH present later during life with signs of hyperandrogenism, very much like in PCOD.

  • Specific testing for CAH is usually reserved for those having early onset hirsutism (pre or peri-menarchal), women with family history of disorder and high-risk ethnic groups like Ashkenazi Jews.

  • A follicular phase morning serum 17 OHP concentration less than 200ng/dl, excludes and a level greater than 800 ng/dl establishes the diagnosis of CAH.

  • Between values of 200-800 ACTH stimulation test needs to be done with intramuscular injection of 0.25 mg ACTH , if the 17 OHP concentration will rise above 1500 mg/dL, it is diagnostic for CAH.

 

Let us look at each option

 

Option. A. Insulin Resistance: Insulin resistance is a common feature of PCOS but is not directly indicated by elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. Insulin resistance is typically assessed through glucose tolerance tests or measurements of fasting insulin levels.

 

Option. B. Cushing Syndrome: Cushing syndrome is characterized by excessive cortisol production. While it can present with features like PCOS, such as weight gain and menstrual irregularities, elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone is not a typical finding in Cushing's.

 

Option C. Androgen Producing Tumors: Androgen-producing tumors can cause symptoms similar to PCOS. However, elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels are more indicative of adrenal disorders like congenital adrenal hyperplasia rather than androgen-producing tumors.

 

Option. D. Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH): Correct. Elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone are a key indicator for congenital adrenal hyperplasia, particularly the 21-hydroxylase deficiency form. In the context of PCOS evaluation, an abnormally high level of 17-hydroxyprogesterone warrants further investigation to exclude CAH.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When evaluating a patient for PCOS, a significantly elevated level of 17-hydroxyprogesterone, as in this case, suggests the need to exclude congenital adrenal hyperplasia, especially the 21-hydroxylase deficiency variant. CAH can mimic many symptoms of PCOS, including hyperandrogenism and menstrual irregularities.

 

Ref: Page 449, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

choices.text: Male pattern hair growth on lower abdomen
High serum levels of high-density lipoproteins

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl with a long-standing history of irregular menstrual cycles and amenorrhea presents with an ultrasound picture shown below. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in her?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. High serum levels of high-density lipoproteins

 

  • PCOD women shows chronic anovulation and commonly shows insulin resistance which is associated with acanthosis and thickening of skin.

  • Insulin resistance leads to abnormal glucose tolerance detected using GTT with 75 gm glucose.

  • Upto10% of women with PCOS develop diabetes by age 40.

 

Metabolic abnormalities in PCOD

 

  • Elevated androgen level leads to increased LDL levels

  • Increased triglyceride levels (>150mg/dl)

  • Normal or decreased HDL levels(<50mg/dl)

  • Hyperinsulinemia

  • Central obesity with increased waist circumference (>88 cm)

 

Let consider each option:

 

Option. A. Male Pattern Hair Growth on Lower Abdomen: Likely. Hirsutism, or male pattern hair growth, is a common feature in PCOS due to hyperandrogenism. This can include hair growth on the lower abdomen.

 

Option. B. Thickened Dark Skin on Inner Thighs: Likely. Acanthosis nigricans, characterized by thickened and darkened skin, often in areas like the neck and inner thighs, is commonly associated with insulin resistance, a condition often seen in PCOS.

 

Option C. Abnormal Glucose Tolerance Test Results: Likely. Women with PCOS are at increased risk for insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. An abnormal glucose tolerance test is a common finding and reflects impaired insulin sensitivity.

 

Option. D. High Serum Levels of High-Density Lipoproteins (HDL): Least likely. PCOS is often associated with a dyslipidemic profile, which typically includes lower levels of HDL ("good" cholesterol) and higher levels of LDL ("bad" cholesterol) and triglycerides. High levels of HDL are not characteristic of the metabolic disturbances commonly seen in PCOS.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

PCOS is often associated with signs of hyperandrogenism like hirsutism, metabolic issues such as insulin resistance and abnormal glucose tolerance, and a dyslipidemic profile with lower HDL levels.

 

 Ref: Page 400, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: During detailed workup of PCOD in a 19-year-old patient shown below is noted to have a serum total testosterone level of 375 ng/dl with rapidly increasing hirsutism. Which of the following endocrine glands is likely to harbour the androgen producing tumour?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Ovary

 

  • The image shown is hirsutism.
  • When the serum total testosterone concentration (>150ng/dl) or the clinical presentation suggests the possibility of rare androgen producing ovarian or adrenal tumours, remember that ovarian tumours are more common than adrenal tumours
  • Androgen secreting tumours of the ovary include
    • Sertoli-Leydig tumours
    • lipid cell tumours
    • Theca cell tumours
    • Brenners tumour
  • A Transvaginal ultrasound is gold standard to detect such tumour.
  • Adrenal tumours are identified by adrenal CT.
  • Most androgen producing adrenal tumours are malignant. Adrenal adenomas are smaller than carcinoma and have smooth borders. CT features of irregular margin, necrosis, haemorrhage, or calcification suggest a carcinoma.

 

Selective ovarian venous catheterization can be considered for the rare patient having no demonstrable ovarian or adrenal mass lesion.

 

Let's consider the potential source of an androgen-producing tumour:

 

Option. A. Pancreas: The pancreas is not typically a source of androgen-producing tumours. It primarily functions in insulin and digestive enzyme production, and its pathologies are not usually associated with elevated androgen levels.

 

Option. B. Adrenal: Adrenal tumours can produce androgens, leading to symptoms like hirsutism. However, ovarian tumours are more common causes of elevated androgens in women. Adrenal tumours are less frequent and are usually identified with adrenal CT imaging.

 

Option C. Ovary: Correct. Ovarian tumours, such as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumours, lipid cell tumours, theca cell tumours, or Brenner tumours, can secrete high levels of androgens. Given the high serum testosterone level and the clinical presentation, an ovarian source is more likely than an adrenal source. Transvaginal ultrasound is typically used for initial evaluation.

 

Option. D. Pituitary: Pituitary tumours, such as prolactinomas or adenomas producing ACTH, can affect menstrual cycles and hormonal balance, but they are not known for directly secreting androgens.

 

Educational Objective: In cases of PCOD with significantly elevated serum testosterone levels and rapidly increasing hirsutism, an androgen-secreting ovarian tumour should be considered. Ovarian tumours are a more common source of excess androgens in women compared to adrenal tumours. Transvaginal ultrasound is the gold standard for detecting such ovarian tumours, while adrenal tumours are identified with adrenal CT imaging

 

Ref: Page 449, Speroff’s Clinical Gynaecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: Which of the following medications added to clomiphene has been found to be associated with improvement in ovulation response?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metformin

 

  • Majority of both lean and obese women with PCOS ARE INSULIN RESISTANT
  • Metformin improves menstrual cyclicity and ovulatory function in women with PCOS.
  • The most appropriate candidate for treatment with metformin along with clomiphene are those:
    • With impaired glucose tolerance or diabetes
    • Those with obvious signs of insulin resistance such as acanthosis nigricans
    • Women with features of metabolic syndrome such as obesity, dyslipidemia, and hypertension

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option. A. Insulin: While insulin resistance is a common feature in PCOS, adding insulin itself is not a standard treatment for improving ovulation.

 

Option. B.   DHEA is a precursor to sex hormones and is sometimes used as a supplement in various fertility treatments. However, its addition to clomiphene for improving ovulation response in PCOS is not well-established or widely recommended.

 

Option. D. Progesterone: Progesterone is used in various contexts in reproductive medicine, but it is not typically added to clomiphene to improve ovulation. Its primary use is in the luteal phase support in assisted reproductive technologies and to induce menstrual cycles in cases of amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objective: Metformin, when used alongside clomiphene, can improve the ovulation response in women with PCOS, particularly those with insulin resistance or metabolic syndrome. Metformin improves insulin sensitivity, thereby enhancing the effectiveness of clomiphene in inducing ovulation

 

Ref: Page 424, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: A 26-year nulligravida married for 4 years with irregular menstrual cycles was being evaluated for infertility. On ultrasonography she has 14 follicles measuring 2-8 mm diameter per ovary (USG picture shown below). What percentage of young women without PCOS will exhibit a similar ultrasonographic picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20

 

  • 8-25% of normal women and 14% of women using OCP meet the USG criteria for PCOD

 

Thus option A) 20 % is correct.

 

Ultrasound features which are considered for diagnosis of polycystic ovaries includes:

 

  • ≥12 follicles measuring 2–9 mm throughout the entire ovary
  • increased ovarian volume of > 10 cm3
  • No subjective assessment of stromal echogenicity and/or follicular distribution pattern required.
    • A single ovary complying these features is sufficient for diagnosing as polycystic ovaries(PCO)
    • Studies have demonstrated that without the symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome, a PCO appearance alone is not associated with impaired fertility

 

Educational Objective: While up to 25% of normal women can exhibit polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, it's crucial to remember that this finding alone, in the absence of clinical symptoms of PCOS, does not indicate impaired fertility or PCOS. The diagnosis of PCOS should be based on a combination of clinical signs, symptoms, and ultrasound findings

 

Ref: Page 401, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

choices.text: Reverses endometrial hyperplasia
Increases angiotensinogen production
Reduces LH levels in the blood
Increases SHBG production

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulliparous female was advised the following contraceptives for irregular periods and hormonal imbalance. Ethinyl estradiol has which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Increases SHBG production

 

  • Estrogen – progestin contraceptives have several complimentary non contraceptive effect actions that make them effective treatment for menstrual irregularities and hirsutism seen in PCOD.
  • The high levels of estrogen in combination contraceptives stimulates hepatic production of SHBG thereby increasing binding capacity for circulating androgens and decreasing the amount of free active androgen.
  • Estrogen induces a dose dependent increase in SHBG concentrations.
    Estrogen component also suppresses FSH in HPO axis

 

Let us  consider each option:

 

Option. A. Reverses Endometrial Hyperplasia: While estrogens can influence the endometrium, they are not typically used alone to reverse endometrial hyperplasia. Progestins are more commonly used for this purpose, as unopposed estrogen can actually increase the risk of endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Option. B. Increases Angiotensinogen Production: Estrogens can increase the production of angiotensinogen in the liver, which can have effects on blood pressure regulation. However, this is not the primary reason for using ethinyl estradiol in combination contraceptives for menstrual irregularities and hormonal imbalance.

 

Option C. Reduces LH Levels in the Blood: Estrogen components in oral contraceptives can suppress LH secretion as part of the feedback mechanism on the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. However, this suppression is typically achieved in combination with a progestin component.

 

Option. D. Increases SHBG Production: Correct. Ethinyl estradiol stimulates hepatic production of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), which binds free testosterone in the bloodstream, thus reducing the level of free and bioavailable androgens. This effect is beneficial in conditions like PCOS, where hyperandrogenism is a concern.

 

Educational Objective: The estrogen component of combination contraceptives, such as ethinyl estradiol, increases the production of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) in the liver. This leads to a reduction in free and bioavailable androgens, which can be beneficial in managing conditions like PCOS that are characterized by hyperandrogenism.

 

Ref: Page 425, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

A minimum of 10 drills in each ovary should be made

It can lead to a reduction in AMH levels

questions.text: A 30yr subfertile  woman who has not responded to ovulation induction with clomiphene citrate undergoes a procedure as shown.  What is true about the procedure being shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It can lead to a reduction in AMH levels

 

  • The procedure shown in Laparoscopic Ovarian Drilling
  • Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is used in place of wedge resection (earlier done) in patients with severe PCOS resistant to clomiphene and have even tried ovulation with gonadotropins
  • Procedure involves use of electrocautery monopolar needle inserted at a cutting current of 100 W for entry and 40W coagulation to treat stroma for a time of 4 seconds. In each ovary 4 punctures are done to reduce adhesion formation to a depth of 4 mm (rule of 4)
  • Most of the studies report reduction in both androgen and LH concentration and an increase in FSH concentration.
  • There is a fall in AMH levels following the procedure
  • However, there is risk of adhesion formation in patients and should be discussed with the patient.
  • The beneficial effects are sustained for up to 5 years.

 

Let's evaluate each statement about this procedure:

 

Option. A. Should be Performed as 1st Line of Treatment in Women Seeking Fertility Issues in PCOS: Incorrect. Ovarian drilling is not the first line of treatment for fertility issues in women with PCOS. Initial treatments usually involve lifestyle modifications and medications like clomiphene citrate or letrozole for ovulation induction. Ovarian drilling is considered when these initial treatments fail.

 

Option. B. A Minimum of 10 Drills in Each Ovary Should be Made: Incorrect. The exact number of drills made during ovarian drilling is variable and depends on the surgeon's discretion and the patient's specific condition. However, making too many drills can damage the ovarian tissue and is not typically recommended.

 

Option C. Used to Mainly Treat Hirsutism: Incorrect. Ovarian drilling is primarily used to induce ovulation in women with PCOS who are resistant to other forms of treatment. While it may have some effect on androgen levels, its main purpose is not to treat hirsutism.

 

Option. D. Can Lead to a Reduction in AMH Levels: Correct. Ovarian drilling can lead to a reduction in anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) levels. AMH is a marker of ovarian reserve, and ovarian drilling, by its nature, can reduce the number of antral follicles, thereby decreasing AMH levels.

 

Educational Objective: Ovarian drilling is a surgical option for inducing ovulation in women with PCOS who are resistant to first-line treatments like clomiphene citrate. While it can be effective in inducing ovulation, it can also lead to a reduction in AMH levels, indicating a decrease in ovarian reserve. It is not primarily used for treating hirsutism and should not be the first-line treatment for fertility issues in PCOS

 

Ref: Page 424, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: All the following are ovulation induction option in PCOD except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ormeloxifene

 

  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome is a common disorder relating to ovulation problems

  • The 1st line of management in a woman desirous of fertility in PCOS in Letrozole (Recent ESHRE guidelines)

  • Earlier Clomiphene citrate was the drug of choice but has mostly been replaced with letrozole.

  • Gonadotropins are used when there is inability to induce ovulation with letrozole or clomiphene. Gonadotropins are used in clomiphene failure.  (2nd line management)

  • When PCOD women do not ovulate with gonadotropins laparoscopic ovarian drilling is planned.

  • Metformin in combination with clomiphene increases ovulation and pregnancy rate as compared to clomiphene alone.

  • Ormeloxifene (Centchroman) is

    • A Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator

    • It is a  non-steroidal oral contraceptive used in a dose of 30mg twice weekly for 3 months and then weekly dose for contraception

    • It is also used for heavy menstrual bleeding in 60 mg twice weekly.

    • It does not induce ovulation.

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option. A. Metformin: Metformin is used in PCOS primarily for its insulin-sensitizing effects, which can help restore normal ovulation, especially in women with insulin resistance. It's often used in combination with other ovulation-inducing drugs.

 

Option. B. Human Menopausal Gonadotropin (HMG): HMG, which contains a mixture of FSH and LH, is used to induce ovulation in women who do not respond to clomiphene. It directly stimulates the ovaries to produce follicles.

 

Option C. Clomiphene: Clomiphene citrate is a first-line therapy for ovulation induction in women with PCOS. It works by blocking estrogen receptors, leading to increased release of FSH and LH, which in turn stimulates follicular growth.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In PCOS, ovulation induction can be achieved with medications like clomiphene citrate, metformin (particularly in insulin-resistant patients), and human menopausal gonadotropin (HMG). Ormeloxifene, however, is not used for this purpose and is instead utilized for contraception and managing dysfunctional uterine bleeding.

 

Ref: Page 424, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: A 23y old woman with PCOS and infertility is started on letrozole for ovulation induction. Letrozole is nowadays preferred over clomiphene in case of PCOS due to which of the following effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  No antiestrogenic effect on endometrium

 

  • Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor. Orally absorbed and t½ is 45h
  • Clomiphene vs Letrozole:

 

 

let's examine each option:

 

Option. A. More Chances of Multiple Pregnancy: Incorrect. Letrozole actually has a lower risk of multiple pregnancies compared to clomiphene.

 

Option. B. More Chances of Ovulation: While letrozole has been shown to be effective in inducing ovulation, especially in women with PCOS, its preference over clomiphene is not solely based on a higher ovulation rate. Both medications are effective for ovulation induction.

 

Option C. No Antiestrogenic Effect on Endometrium: Correct. One of the key advantages of letrozole over clomiphene is that it does not have the antiestrogenic effects on the endometrium and cervical mucus that clomiphene does. Clomiphene can lead to a thin endometrial lining, which can be counterproductive for conception.

 

Option. D. Increased Chances of Poly-Follicular Development: Incorrect. Letrozole typically results in a more physiologic ovulation process with fewer risks of poly-follicular development compared to clomiphene.

 

Educational Objective: Letrozole is often preferred over clomiphene for ovulation induction in women with PCOS due to its lack of antiestrogenic effects on the endometrium. While both letrozole and clomiphene are effective in inducing ovulation, letrozole's more favorable impact on the endometrial lining makes it a better choice in certain scenarios, particularly in women with PCOS

 

Ref: Page 424, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: The most common metabolic abnormality associated with PCOS is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Insulin Resistance

 

Insulin resistance is indeed one of the most common metabolic abnormalities associated with PCOS. It is a key factor in the pathophysiology of the syndrome and contributes to various other metabolic complications, including type 2 diabetes.

 

  • Nearly 70% have at least one borderline or elevated lipid level.
  • Prevalence of obesity is around 50% in PCOS


Metabolic abnormalities in PCOD

 

  • Elevated androgen level leads to increased LDL levels
  • Increased triglyceride levels (>150mg/dl)
  • Normal or decreased HDL levels(<50mg/dl)
  • Hyperinsulinemia
  • Central obesity with increased waist circumference (>88 cm)

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option. B. Acanthosis Nigricans: Acanthosis nigricans, a skin condition characterized by darkened and thickened patches, often in the neck and groin areas, is associated with insulin resistance, a common feature in PCOS. However, it is more of a clinical sign than a metabolic abnormality.

 

Option. D. Hyperandrogenism: Hyperandrogenism, while a defining feature of PCOS, is more of an endocrine abnormality than a metabolic one. It manifests clinically as hirsutism, acne, and alopecia.

 

Educational Objective: The most common metabolic abnormality associated with PCOS is insulin resistance, which plays a central role in the pathophysiology of the syndrome and is linked to various metabolic complications. While dyslipidaemia is also common in PCOS, insulin resistance is more fundamental to the disorder's metabolic disturbances.

 

Ref: Page 449,416, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: All of the following are long term effects of PCOS except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Breast malignancy

 

Management of PCOD should correct both its immediate and long-term clinical consequences which include:

 

  • Menstrual irregularities
  • Increased risk of developing endometrial hyperplasia and neoplasia
  • Hyperandrogenism
  • Infertility
  • Increased risk of developing type 2 DM
  • Increased risk of developing cardiovascular disease
  • OBESITY and associated obstructive sleep apnea
  • Increase in prevalence of anxiety, depression, and mood disorders
  • Metabolic syndrome
    • Even though PCOD is associated with Hyperestrogenic state there is no positive correlation with breast carcinoma and PCOD.

 

Let's analyze each option to determine which is not a long-term effect:

 

Option. A. Ovarian Malignancy: While PCOS is associated with a number of reproductive and metabolic complications, a direct link between PCOS and increased risk of ovarian cancer is not clearly established. PCOS is primarily associated with an increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer due to prolonged unopposed estrogen exposure.

 

Option. B. Obstructive Sleep Apnoea: Correct. Obstructive sleep apnea is more common in women with PCOS, often related to the higher prevalence of obesity in this population. Obesity, a common feature in PCOS, is a risk factor for obstructive sleep apnoea.

 

Option C. Endometrial Hyperplasia: Correct. Women with PCOS are at an increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial cancer due to chronic anovulation, leading to prolonged estrogen exposure without the counterbalancing effect of progesterone.

 

Option. D. Breast Malignancy: exception. Despite the hyperestrogenic state associated with PCOS, there is no established positive correlation between PCOS and an increased risk of breast cancer. The increased risk of malignancy in PCOS is more specifically related to the endometrium.

 

Educational Objective: While PCOS is associated with several long-term health consequences, including menstrual irregularities, infertility, metabolic syndrome, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and endometrial hyperplasia, there is no established direct link between PCOS and an increased risk of breast cancer. The management of PCOS should address both its immediate symptoms and long-term health risks.

 

Ref: Page 416, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

choices.text: Flow cytometry of the peripheral blood

questions.text: An infant is born with ambiguous genitalia. Although amniocentesis analysis during pregnancy showed a 46XX genotype, this infant has phallic-appearing genitalia and partially fused labia. You cannot palpate testes. Aside from a standard blood test, which biochemical screen is indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels

 

  • This infant likely has congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).
  • The classic form of 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD) is the most common cause of CAH.
  • It has an incidence between 1 in 10,000 and 1 in 15,000 and is the most common cause of androgenization in chromosomal 46,XX females.
  • Affected individuals are homozygous or compound heterozygous for severe mutations in the enzyme 21-hydroxylase (CYP21A2). This mutation causes a block in adrenal glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid synthesis, increasing 17-hydroxyprogesterone and shunting steroid precursors into the androgen synthesis pathway.
  • Increased androgen synthesis in utero causes androgenization of the 46,XX fetus in the first trimester.
  • Ambiguous genitalia are seen at birth, with varying degrees of clitoral enlargement and labial fusion.
  • The salt-wasting form of 21-OHD results from severe combined glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiency.
  • A salt-wasting crisis usually manifests between 5 and 21 days of life and is a potentially life-threatening event that requires urgent fluid resuscitation and steroid treatment.
  • Thus, a diagnosis of 21-OHD should be considered in any baby with atypical genitalia with bilateral non palpable gonads.

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option. A. Flow Cytometry of the Peripheral Blood: Flow cytometry is not typically used in the initial evaluation of ambiguous genitalia. It is more commonly used for immunological analyses and is not directly relevant to determining the cause of ambiguous genitalia.

 

Option. B. Serum Cortisol Levels: While serum cortisol levels might be relevant in cases of adrenal insufficiency, they are not the most direct initial test for an infant with ambiguous genitalia. Cortisol levels may be part of the broader evaluation but are not the primary test for diagnosing congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).

 

Option. D. Serum TSH: It is used to screen for thyroid disorders but is not the primary test for evaluating ambiguous genitalia. TSH levels would not typically be elevated in cases of CAH or other conditions leading to virilization.

 

Educational Objective: In infants with ambiguous genitalia and a 46XX genotype, serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels should be assessed to screen for congenital adrenal hyperplasia, particularly 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This condition leads to increased androgen synthesis, causing virilization in chromosomal 46, XX females. Prompt diagnosis is crucial for appropriate management and prevention of potentially life-threatening adrenal crises.

 

 Ref: Page 266, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: A young lady presents to the Gynecology OPD with complaints of primary infertility, excessive weight gain and hirsutism. Laparoscopy shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. PCOS 

 

  • Laparoscopic image shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries seen in Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • PCOS is a common functional disorder of the ovaries of unknown etiology.
  • A diagnosis of PCOS must meet 2 out of 3 criteria: Rotterdam Criteria
    1. Androgen excess with clinical hyperandrogenism or elevated serum free or total testosterone
    2. Ovarian dysfunction with oligo/anovulation
    3. Ultrasound showing polycystic morphology in 1 or both ovaries.

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option. A. Turner’s Syndrome: Turner’s syndrome is characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome (45XO) and is typically associated with features such as short stature, webbed neck, and primary amenorrhea. It is not associated with PCOS-like symptoms or the laparoscopic findings described.

 

Option. B. Pituitary Adenoma: A pituitary adenoma can cause menstrual irregularities and infertility due to hormonal imbalances, particularly if it is a prolactin-secreting adenoma. However, it would not cause the specific laparoscopic findings associated with PCOS.

 

Option. D. Bilateral Dysgerminoma: Bilateral dysgerminoma is a rare type of ovarian tumor. The presentation would be more acute and could include abdominal pain or a palpable mass, which are not described in this scenario. The laparoscopic findings typical for PCOS are not consistent with dysgerminoma.

 

Educational Objective: The most likely diagnosis for a young woman presenting with primary infertility, weight gain, hirsutism, and characteristic laparoscopic findings of enlarged, polycystic ovaries is PCOS. PCOS is a common endocrine disorder that affects women of reproductive age and is characterized by hyperandrogenism, ovulatory dysfunction, and polycystic ovaries.

 

Ref: Page 400, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

choices.text: Ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: Pearl necklace appearance is characteristic in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. PCOS

 

POLYCYSTIC OVARIAN DISEASE (PCOD)

 

  • It is a heterogeneous syndrome complex.
  • Characterized by chronic anovulation and hyperandrogenism.
  • Frequently associated with insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility & hirsutism

 

Diagnosis

 

Rotterdam 2003 criteria for diagnosis of PCOS/PCOD—at least two out of three should be present

 

  1. Oligo/anovulation
  2. Hyperandrogenism: biochemical or clinical
  3. On USG: Twelve or more than 12 follicles 2–9 mm in size present within one or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume >10 mL.

 

Management

 

Principles of management include:

 

  • Irregular periods/amenorrhea = regularization of menses with OC pills/cyclical progesterone
  • Hirsutism/acne = suppression of androgens
  • Infertility = ovulation induction (preferred drug: Letrozole; Clomiphene citrate can also be given; 2nd line of drugs: Gonadotropins)
  • Insulin sensitizers like metformin  are also used to tackle insulin resistance

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option. A. Ectopic Pregnancy: The embryo implants outside the uterine cavity (most commonly in the fallopian tube). They might show an adnexal mass and an absence of an intrauterine gestational sac.

 

Option C. Endometriosis: It involves the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, ultrasound findings vary and can include cysts (endometriomas) or adhesions.

 

Option. D. PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease): In PID, an infection of the female reproductive organs, ultrasound findings might include thickened fluid-filled fallopian tubes or other signs of inflammation.

 

Educational Objective: The "pearl necklace" appearance on ultrasound, characterized by multiple small follicles around the periphery of the ovary, is a hallmark sign of PCOS. This appearance helps in the diagnosis of PCOS, a common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age.

 

Ref: Page 400, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility 9th edition

questions.text: What is not used in PCOS?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Danazol

 

POLYCYSTIC OVARIAN DISEASE (PCOD)

 

  • It is a heterogeneous syndrome complex.
  • Characterized by chronic anovulation and hyperandrogenism.
  • Frequently associated with insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility & hirsutism

 

Diagnosis

 

Rotterdam 2003 criteria for diagnosis of PCOS/PCOD—at least two out of three should be present

 

  1. Oligo/anovulation
  2. Hyperandrogenism: biochemical or clinical
  3. On USG: Twelve or more than 12 follicles 2–9 mm in size present within one or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume >10 mL.

 

Management

 

Principles of management include:

 

  • Irregular periods/amenorrhea = regularization of menses with OC pills/cyclical progesterone
  • Hirsutism/acne = suppression of androgens
  • Infertility = ovulation induction (preferred drug: Letrozole; Clomiphene citrate can also be given; 2nd line of drugs: Gonadotropins)
  • Insulin sensitizers like metformin  are also used to tackle insulin resistance

 

Let us look at each option:


Option. A. OC Pills (Oral Contraceptive Pills): Commonly prescribed in PCOS for regularizing menstrual cycles, decreasing androgen levels, and improving symptoms such as hirsutism and acne.

 

Option. B. Cyclical Progesterone: Cyclical progesterone can be used to induce regular menstrual bleeding, thereby reducing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia, which can result from anovulation and prolonged estrogen exposure in PCOS.

 

Option C. Myo-Inositol: Myo-inositol is a supplement that has been shown to improve insulin resistance and ovarian function in women with PCOS, and it may help in restoring fertility and normalizing menstrual cycles.

 

Option. D. Danazol: Not used in PCOS. Danazol is an androgenic medication primarily used in the treatment of endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease. Due to its androgenic effects, it is not suitable for treating PCOS, a condition already characterized by hyperandrogenism.

 

Educational Objective: In PCOS, treatment options include oral contraceptive pills, cyclical progesterone, and supplements like myo-inositol, which help in managing symptoms and reducing long-term risks. Danazol, due to its androgenic properties, is not used in PCOS management, as it may exacerbate symptoms related to hyperandrogenism.

 

Ref: Page 424, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility 9th edition

choices.text: Bishop score
Rotterdam criteria
All of the above

questions.text: Which of the following is used in quantifying hirsutism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ferriman-Gallwey score

 

  • The Ferriman-Gallwey Score: Method used for evaluating and quantifying hirsutism in women.
  • It is a score which quantifies the amount of hair (1-4) in 9 areas of the body (upper lip/ chin/ upper back/ lower back/ breast/ upper abdomen/ lower abdomen/ upper arm/ thighs)
  • A score of > 8 is significant to call it clinical hyperandrogenism

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option. A. Bishop Score: The Bishop score is used in obstetrics to assess the readiness of the cervix for labor, evaluating factors such as dilation, effacement, station, consistency, and position of the cervix

 

Option. B. Rotterdam Criteria: The Rotterdam criteria are used for diagnosing polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). They include hyperandrogenism (clinical or biochemical), oligo/anovulation, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound.

 

Option. D. All of the Above: Incorrect, as only the Ferriman-Gallwey score is used for quantifying hirsutism. The Bishop score and Rotterdam criteria serve different purposes in obstetrics and PCOS diagnosis, respectively.

 

Educational Objective: The Ferriman-Gallwey score is the standardized method used to quantify the extent and severity of hirsutism. It assesses hair growth in various areas of the body that are typically less hairy in females, providing a useful tool in diagnosing and assessing the severity of conditions like PCOS.

 

Ref: Page 450, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: Which of the following findings favor the diagnosis of androgenic tumor over PCOS in a woman presenting with amenorrhea and hirsutism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Clitoromegaly

 

CLINICAL FEATURES OF PCOS:

 

  • MC - Anovulatory infertility/amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea

  • Sometimes menorrhagia

  • Acanthosis nigricans – cutaneous marker of IR

  • Hirsutism

  • Thick terminal hair with male pattern of distribution

  • Acne

  • Alopecia

  • Ferriman gallwey scoring ≥ 8

  • Virilization – NEVER SEEN (seen in androgenic tumors)

  • Clitoromegaly

  • Hoarseness of voice

  • Increased muscle mass

  • Male pattern baldness

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option. A. Acne: Acne is a common symptom of PCOS due to hyperandrogenism

 

Option. B. Alopecia: Androgenic alopecia (male-pattern hair loss) can occur in both PCOS and androgenic tumors due to increased androgen levels.

 

Option C. Clitoromegaly: Correct. Clitoromegaly, or enlargement of the clitoris, is a sign of significant androgen excess and is more suggestive of an androgen-secreting tumor than PCOS.

 

Option. D. Testosterone Level of 150 ng/dl: While elevated testosterone levels are seen in PCOS, a level as high as 150 ng/dl is unusual and would raise suspicion for an androgen-secreting tumor. However, clitoromegaly is a more definitive clinical sign that favours an androgenic tumor over PCOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clitoromegaly is a key clinical finding that favours the diagnosis of an androgen-secreting tumor over PCOS in a woman presenting with amenorrhea and hirsutism. This sign indicates a higher level of androgen excess than typically seen in PCOS. In contrast, symptoms like acne and alopecia can occur in both conditions.

 

Ref: Page 449, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility 9th edition

choices.text: A, B & C are correct
A & B are correct

D & E are correct

questions.text:
Ultrasonographic criteria for the diagnosis of PCOD include?

 

  1. Number of follicles/ovaries
  2. Ovarian volume
  3. Stromal volume
  4. Stromal echogenicity
  5. Stromal blood flow
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A & B are correct

 

According to the consensus definition, polycystic ovaries are present when:

 

  1. One or both ovaries demonstrate 12 or more follicles measuring 2-9 mm in diameter and/or
  2.  The ovarian volume exceeds 10 cm3.
  • Only one ovary meeting either of these criteria is sufficient to establish the presence of polycystic ovaries
  • Stromal Echogenicity and Volume have been described, but do not contribute to formal diagnostic criteria.
  • Stromal blood flow is not included in ultrasonographic diagnostic criteria for PCOD
     

Updated Ultrasonographic criteria for the diagnosis of PCOD by ESHRE guidelines 2018
 

  • Ovaries may be normal in PCOS, and conversely, polycystic ovarian morphology (PCOM) may be seen in women without the syndrome. However, it is well accepted that women with PCOS tend to have larger ovaries with an increased number of follicles.
  • The updated diagnostic criteria at the time of review are based on a 2018 International consensus guideline (ESHRE guideline)
  • In patients > 8 years post menarche, and using a high-frequency endo-vaginal probe  (8MHz)
    1. Follicle number per ovary (FNPO) ≥ 20, and/or
    2. Ovarian volume ≥10 mL, ensuring no corpora lutea, cysts or dominant follicles are present
  • If using transabdominal scanning, or older technology where ovarian morphology is not well visualized, consider using the ovarian volume threshold of ≥10 ml on either ovary.
  • The diagnostic criteria are adjusted in adolescent females (defined as within 8 years of menarche, or age <20 years), in whom ultrasound should not be used for the diagnosis of PCOS due to the high incidence of multi-follicular ovaries in this life stage.
  • This supersedes the initial Rotterdam criteria of ≥ 12 follicles.
  • The presence of a single multi-follicular ovary is sufficient to provide the sonographic criterion for PCOS
  • Other morphological features have been described, but do not contribute to formal diagnostic criteria:
    1. Stromal Echogenicity and Volume (hyperechoic central stroma)
    2. Peripheral location of follicles (string of pearls sign)
    3. Follicles of similar size measuring 2-9 mm

Let us look at each option:

 

Option. A. Number of Follicles/Ovaries: Correct. One of the criteria for PCOS on ultrasound is the presence of a high number of follicles in the ovaries. According to the Rotterdam criteria, this is typically defined as 12 or more follicles measuring 2-9 mm in diameter in each ovary.

 

Option. B. Ovarian Volume: Correct. Another ultrasonographic criterion for PCOS is increased ovarian volume. The Rotterdam criteria define this as an ovarian volume greater than 10 cm³.

 

Option C. Stromal Volume: While stromal volume may be increased in PCOS, it is not a specific criterion for the diagnosis on ultrasound. The diagnosis is more commonly based on the number of follicles and ovarian volume.

 

Option. D. Stromal Echogenicity: Increased stromal echogenicity can be seen in PCOS, but it is not part of the standard criteria fordiagnosis on ultrasound.

 

Option. E. Stromal Blood Flow: Changes in stromal blood flow may occur in PCOS; however, it is not a defined criterion for its diagnosis in ultrasonography.

 

The correct answer is B) A & B are correct, as the number of follicles per ovary and ovarian volume are key ultrasonographic criteria for diagnosing PCOS.

 

Educational Objective: The ultrasonographic criteria for diagnosing PCOS include the presence of 12 or more follicles measuring 2-9 mm in diameter per ovary and/or increased ovarian volume (>10 cm³). These criteria are part of the Rotterdam criteria for the diagnosis of PCOS and are essential in the assessment of this condition

 

Ref: Page 401, Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: In galactorrhea-amenorrhea syndrome, the investigation you should advise apart from serum prolactin levels is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. TSH

 

  • Hyperprolactinemia leads to both galactorrhea and amenorrhea.
  • Prolactin secretion is controlled by a prolactin inhibitor factor that is secreted from the hypothalamus.
  • Other factors like vasoactive inhibitory peptide (VIP) and thyroid releasing hormone (TRH) cause increased prolactin secretion.
  • In fact, TRH in addition to increasing TSH causes a rise in prolactin levels. In patients with galactorrhea-amenorrhea S.TSH should be evaluated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperprolactinemia leads to both galactorrhea and amenorrhea.

 

Ref: Page 401, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology, and Infertility 9th edition

choices.text: Elevated LH, ratio of LH/FSH is > 3:1
Reversible estradiol: estrone ratio
Reduced SHBG level.
Reduced serum insulin level.

questions.text: Which of the following serum values is NOT in favour of diagnosis of PCOS?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Reduced serum insulin level

 

  • LH level is elevated and/or ratio of LH: FSH is > 3:1
  • Reversed estradiol: estrone ratio- The estrone level is markedly elevated.
  • SHBG level is reduced.
  • Androstenedione level is elevated.
  • Serum testosterone and DHEA may be marginally elevated.
  • Raised serum insulin level
  • Ratio of fasting glucose: fasting insulin is < 4.5

 

Let us review each option:

 

Option. A. Elevated LH, Ratio of LH/FSH is > 3:1: Elevated LH and a high LH/FSH ratio are common findings in PCOS. An elevated ratio often reflects the altered hormonal environment characteristic of PCOS

 

Option. B. Reversible Estradiol: Estrone Ratio: In PCOS, there can be an altered ratio of estradiol to estrone. This change is due to increased peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogens, particularly in adipose tissue. While this change can be seen in PCOS, it's not as specific or diagnostic as other hormonal alterations.

 

Option C. Reduced SHBG Level: Reduced levels of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) are a typical finding in PCOS. Lower SHBG leads to higher levels of free androgens, contributing to the hyperandrogenism seen in PCOS.

 

Option. D. Reduced Serum Insulin Level: Correct as the exception. PCOS is often associated with insulin resistance, which typically leads to elevated, not reduced, insulin levels. Reduced serum insulin levels would not typically support a diagnosis of PCOS.

 

Educational Objective: In diagnosing PCOS, typical hormonal findings include elevated LH levels, a high LH/FSH ratio, reduced SHBG levels, and often elevated insulin levels due to insulin resistance. Reduced serum insulin levels are not characteristic of PCOS and would not support its diagnosis.

 

Ref: Page 419, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility 9th edition

choices.text: OC pills containing cyproterone acetate

questions.text: A 19-year-old unmarried girl presents with irregular periods, acne and facial hair. The best treatment for her is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. OC pills containing cyproterone

 

  • PCOS is a heterogeneous syndrome complex characterized by chronic anovulation with androgen excess and frequently associated with insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility, acne and hirsutism.
  • Oral contraceptive pills are the first-line therapy drug of choice for PCOS patients with menstrual abnormalities and hirsutism, acne (Not wanting fertility)
  • OC pills will make the menstrual cycles regular and suppress acne and hirsutism.
  • Cyproterone is a progesterone with anti-androgenic properties and hence it is best for those patients who have androgen excess.
  • Cyclical progesterone treatment will only regularize the cycles and will not help in treatment of acne and hirsutism.

 

Let us consider the best treatment options:

 

Option. A. Clomiphene Citrate: Clomiphene citrate is primarily used for ovulation induction in women with infertility, particularly in those with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). It is not the best choice for treating acne and hirsutism.

 

Option. B. Cyclical Progesterone Tablets: Cyclical progesterone can be used to regulate menstrual cycles in cases of anovulation or irregular periods. However, it doesn't directly address hyperandrogenism symptoms such as acne and facial hair.

 

Option C. OC Pills Containing Levonorgestrel: Oral contraceptives containing levonorgestrel can regularize menstrual cycles and provide contraception. However, levonorgestrel is a more androgenic progestin and might not be the best choice for treating acne and hirsutism.

 

Option. D. OC Pills Containing Cyproterone Acetate: Correct. Oral contraceptive pills containing cyproterone acetate are effective in treating symptoms of hyperandrogenism such as acne and hirsutism, in addition to regulating menstrual cycles. Cyproterone acetate has anti-androgenic properties, making it particularly suitable for these symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: In young women with symptoms of hyperandrogenism (such as acne and hirsutism) and irregular periods, oral contraceptive pills containing anti-androgenic progestins like cyproterone acetate are often the best treatment option. These pills help regulate menstrual cycles and directly address androgen-related symptoms.

 

Ref: Page 423, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility 9th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option for PCOS?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulipristal acetate

 

  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • A diagnosis of PCOS must meet 2 out of 3 criteria (Rotterdam Criteria)
    1.  Androgen excess with clinical hyperandrogenism or elevated serum free or total testosterone
    2. Ovarian dysfunction with oligo/ anovulation
    3. Polycystic ovary morphology on ultrasound

 

Treatment

 

  • Lifestyle Modifications
  • If the patient wishes to become pregnant (Desirous of fertility)
    • Letrozole: 1st line drug for ovulation induction
    • Clomiphene can also be used for ovarian stimulation.
    • Metformin can improve menstruation but has little or no benefit in treating infertility; it is beneficial for metabolic or glucose abnormalities.
    • 2nd line: gonadotropins and Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
  • If the patient does not desire pregnancy:
    • Combined OCP
    • Medroxyprogesterone acetate, 10 mg daily orally for the latter half of the cycle (Day 15-25)
    • The levonorgestrel-containing IUD is another option to minimize uterine bleeding and protect against endometrial hyperplasia.
  • Hirsutism
    • A low-dose combination oral contraceptive (progesterone component of the pill should preferably be cyproterone acetate or Drospirenone) for at least 6–12 months.
    • Spironolactone is also useful in doses of 25 mg three or four times daily orally.
    • Flutamide, 125–250 mg once daily orally, and finasteride, 5 mg once daily orally, are also effective
    • Because spironolactone, flutamide, and finasteride are potentially teratogenic, they should only be used with secure contraception.
    • Topical eflornithine cream applied to affected facial areas twice daily for 6 months may be helpful.

 

let's summarize each option:

 

Option. A. Clomiphene Citrate: Used for Induction of ovulation in women with PCOS, particularly those who are experiencing infertility.

 

Option. B. Ulipristal Acetate: Correct as the exception. Ulipristal acetate is used as an emergency contraceptive and for the treatment of uterine fibroids. It is not a treatment option for PCOS, which requires management of symptoms like irregular menstrual cycles, hyperandrogenism, and insulin resistance.

 

Option C. Ovarian Drilling: Ovarian drilling used particularly in women who do not respond to ovulation-inducing medications. It can help to restore ovulation by reducing ovarian androgen production.

 

Option. D. Letrozole: Letrozole is used in the treatment of PCOS for ovulation induction, especially in women who are trying to conceive. It has been found to be effective in inducing ovulation and improving pregnancy rates in women with PCOS.

 

Educational Objective: In the management of PCOS, common treatments include clomiphene citrate and letrozole for ovulation induction and ovarian drilling as a surgical option for those not responding to medication. Ulipristal acetate, used for emergency contraception and uterine fibroids, is not a treatment option for PCOS

 

 

Ref: Page 424, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility 9th edition

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with infertility, irregular menstrual cycles, and hirsutism, is diagnosed to have polycystic ovarian syndrome. All of the following are treatment options in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. OCPs

 

  • PCOS can be managed in women desirous of fertility with ovulation induction drugs

  • These include

    1. Letrozole (drug of choice)

    2. Clomiphene citrate

    3. Gonadotropins

    4. Other drugs like tamoxifen also have been used to cause ovulation induction in women with PCOS

    5. Metformin alone or in combination with clomiphene citrate helps induce ovulation especially in women with high insulin resistance

  • OCPs can be given to women with PCOS with irregular cycle who ARE NOT desirous of fertility.

  • Since this woman has infertility, OCPs should be the answer.

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option A. Letrozole: it is the drug od choice for ovulation induction in PCOS. 

 

Option. B. Clomiphene Citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a common first-line treatment for infertility in PCOS. It induces ovulation by blocking estrogen receptors, leading to increased FSH and LH production.

 

Option C. Metformin: Metformin is used in PCOS, especially in patients with insulin resistance. It can improve menstrual regularity and ovulation, and it is beneficial for metabolic aspects of PCOS.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In treating PCOS, clomiphene citrate and metformin are common options, especially when addressing infertility. OCPs are used for managing menstrual irregularities and hyperandrogenism but are not suitable for treating infertility due to their contraceptive nature. Tamoxifen is not typically used in PCOS treatment but can be used for ovulation induction.

 

Ref: Page 424, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility 9th edition
